And led thro' weary ways;
The lamp of day new lighted,
With joy the dawn ſurveys.
The riſing proſpects viewing,
Each look is forward caſt;
He ſmiles, his courſe purſuing,
Nor thinks of what is paſt.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Hiſt, ſtay! don't I hear a noiſe?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: (within) Well, but dear, dear aunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: (within) You need not ſpeak to me, for it does not ſignify.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Adwawns they are coming here, ecod I'll get out of the way;—Murrain take it this door is bolted now—So ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Get along, get along; (driving in Lucinda before her) you are a ſcandal to the name of Woodcock! but I was reſolved to find you out, for I have ſuſpected you a great while, though your father ſilly man, will have you ſuch a poor innocent.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: What ſhall I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: I was determined to diſcover what you, and your pretended muſic matter were about; and lay in wait on purpoſe: I believe he thought to eſcape me, by ſlipping into the cloſet when I knocked at the door; but I was even with him, for now I have him under lock and key, and pleaſe the fates, there he ſhall remain till your father comes in: I will convince him of his error, whether he will or not.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: You won't be ſo cruel, I am ſure you won't; I thought I had made you my friend, by telling you the truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Del.
sp.p:
Telling me the truth quotha? did I not overhear your ſcheme of running away to night, through the partition; did not I find the very bundles packed up in the room with you ready for going off? No brazenface, I found out the truth by my own ſagacity, though
your father ſays, I am a fool; but now we'll be judged who is the greateſt.—And you Mr. raſcal, my brother ſhall know what an honeſt ſervant he has got.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: You were to have been aiding and aſſiſting them in their eſcape, and have been the go between it ſeems, the letter carrier!

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Who me madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Yes, you ſirrah!

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Miſs Lucinda, did I ever carry a letter for you? I'll make my affidavy before his worſhip—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb,
sp.p: Go, go, you are a villain, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I own aunt I have been very faulty in this affair; I don't pretend to excuſe myſelf; but we are all ſubject to frailties, conſider that, and judge of me by yourſelf, who were once young, and inexperienced as I am.

lg.head: AIR XXXV.
lg.l: If ever a fond inclination,
Roſe in your boſom, to rob you of reſt;
Reflect with a little compaſſion,
On the ſoft pangs, which prevail'd in my breaſt.
Oh where, where would you fly me,
Can you deny me, thus torn, and diſtreſt;
Think when my lover was by me,
Would I, how cou'd I, refuſe his requeſt?
Kneeling before you, let me implore you;
Look on me ſighing, crying, dying;
Ah! is there no language can move?
If I have been too complying!
Hard was the conflict 'twixt duty, and love.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: This is mighty pretty romantick ſtuff! but you learn it out of your play books, and novels. Girls in my time, had other employments, we work'd at our needles, and kept ourſelves from idle thoughts: before I was your age, I had finiſhed with my own fingers, a compleat ſet of chairs, and a fire ſcreen in tent ſtitch; four counterpanes, in Marſailles quilting; and the creed, and the ten commandments, in the hair of our family: it was framed, and glazed, and hung over the parlour chimney piece, and your grandfather was prouder of it, than of e'er a picture in his houſe. I never looked into a book, but when I ſaid my prayers, except it was the compleat houſewife, or the great family receipt book: whereas you are always at your ſtudies: Ah! I never knew a woman come to good, that was fond of reading.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Well, pray madam, let me prevail on you to give me the key to let Mr. Euſtace out, and I promiſe, I never will proceed a ſtep farther in this buſineſs, without your advice and approbation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Have not I told you already my reſolution?—Where are my clogs and my bonnet? I'll go out to my brother in the fields; I'm a fool you know child, now let's ſee what the wits will think of themſelves,—Don't hold me—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I'm not going;—I have thought of a way to be even with you, ſo you may do as you pleaſe.

Well, I thought it would come to this, I'll be ſhot if I didn't;—So here's a fine jobb—But what can they do to me;—They can't ſend me to jail for carrying a letter, ſeeing there was no treaſon in it; and how was I obligated to know my maſter did not allow of their meetings:—The worſt they can do, is to turn me off, and I am ſure the place is no ſuch great purchaſe;—indeed, I ſhall be ſorry to leave Mrs. Roſſetta, ſeeing as how matters are ſo near being brought to an end, betwixt us; but ſhe and I may keep company all as one: and I finds Madge has been ſpeaking with gaffer Broadwheels, the waggoner, about her carriage up to London; ſo that I have got rid of ſhe, and I am ſure I have reaſon to be main glad of it, for ſhe led me a wearyſome life;—But that's the way of them all.

lg.head: AIR. XXXVI.
lg.l: A plague of thoſe wenches, they make ſuch a pother,
When once they have let'n a man have his will;
They're always a whining for ſomething or other,
And cry he's unkind in his carriage:
What tho'f he ſpeaks them ne'er ſo fairly
Still they keep teazing, teazing on:
You cannot perſuade 'em:
'Till promiſe you've made 'em.
And after they've got it,
They tell you—add rot it!
Their character's blaſted, they're ruin'd, undone;
And then, to be ſure, ſir,
There is but one cure, ſir,
And all the diſcourſe is of marriage.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: I am glad I had the precaution to bring this ſuit of cloaths in my bundle, though I hardly know myſelf in them again, they appear ſo ſtrange, and feel ſo unwieldy. However, my gardener's jacket goes on no more.—I wonder this girl does not come (looking at his watch); perhaps ſhe won't come—Why, then I'll go into the village, take a poſt- chaiſe, and depart without any farther ceremony.

lg.head: AIR XXXVII.
lg.l: How much ſuperior beauty awes,
The coldeſt boſoms find;
But with reſiſtleſs force it draws,
To ſenſe and ſweetneſs join'd.
The caſket, where, to outward ſhow,
The workman's art is ſeen,
Is doubly valu'd, when we know
It holds a gem within.

sp.p: Hark! ſhe comes.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter Sir WILLIAM MEADOWS and HAWTHORN.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Confuſion! my father! What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
Tom, are not you a ſad boy, Tom, to bring me a hundred and forty miles, here.—May I never
do an ill turn, but you deſerve to have your head broke; and I have a good mind, partly.—What, ſirrah, don't you think it worth your while to ſpeak to me?

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Forgive me, ſir, I own I have been in a fault.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: In a fault! to run away from me becauſe I was going to do you good.—May I never do an ill turn, maſter Hawthorn, if I did not pick out as fine a girl for him, partly, as any in England; and the raſcal run away from me, and came here and turn'd gardener.—And pray what did you propoſe to yourſelf, Tom? I know you were always fond of Bottany, as they call it; did you intend to keep the trade going, and advertiſe fruit-trees and flowering-ſhrubs, to be had at Meadows's nurſery?

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: No, ſir William, I apprehend the young gentleman deſigned to lay by the profeſſion; for he has quitted the habit already.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: I am ſo aſtoniſhed to ſee you here, ſir, that I don't know what to ſay; but, I aſſure you, if you had not come, I ſhould have returned home to you directly. Pray, ſir, how did you find me out?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No matter, Tom, no matter; it was partly by accident, as a body may ſay; but what does that ſignify—tell me, boy, how ſtands your ſtomach towards matrimony? Do you think you could digeſt a wife now?

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, don't mention it; I ſhall always behave myſelf as a dutiful ſon ought: I will never marry without your conſent, and I hope you won't force me to do it againſt my own.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Is not this mighty provoking, maſter Hawthorn? Why, ſirrah, did you ever ſee the lady I deſigned for you?

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Sir, I don't doubt the lady's merit; but, at preſent, I am not diſpoſed.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Nay, but young gentleman, fair and ſoftly, you ſhould pay ſome reſpect to your father in this matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Reſpect, maſter Hawthorn! may I never do an ill turn, but he ſhall marry her, or I'll diſinherit him! there's once. Look you, Tom, not to make any more words of the matter, I have brought the lady here with me, and I'll ſee you contracted before we part; or you ſhall delve and plant cucumbers as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Have you brought the lady here, ſir? I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why ſorry? what, then you won't marry her? we'll ſee that; pray, maſter Hawthorn, conduct the fair one in.—Ay, ſir, you may fret, and dance about, trot at the rate of fifteen miles an hour, if you pleaſe; but may I never do an ill turn, but I am reſolved.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Sir WILLIAM MEADOWS, HAWTHORN, Young MEADOWS, ROSSETTA.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Here is the lady, ſir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come in, madam, but turn your face from him—he would not marry you becauſe he had not ſeen you; but I'll let him know my choice ſhall be his, and he ſhall conſent to marry you before he ſees you, or not an acre of eſtate.—Pray, ſir, walk this way.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot help thinking your conduct a little extraordinary; but, ſince you urge me ſo cloſely, I muſt tell you my affections are engaged.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How, Tom! how!

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: I was determined, ſir, to have got the better of my inclination, and never have done a thing which I knew would be diſagreeable to you.—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, who are your affections engaged to? let me know that.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: To a perſon, ſir, whoſe rank and fortune may be no recommendations to her; but whoſe charms and accompliſhments entitle her to a monarch. I am ſorry, ſir, it's impoſſible for me to comply with your commands, and I hope you will not be offended if I quit your preſence.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Not I, not in the leaſt; go about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Sir, I obey.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Now is your time, madam.

lg.head: AIR XXXVIII.
lg.l: When we ſee a lover languiſh,
And his truth and honour prove,
Ah! how ſweet to heal his anguiſh,
And repay him love for love.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, Tom, will you go away from me now?

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Perhaps, ſir William, your ſon does not like the lady; and, if ſo, pray don't put a force upon his inclination.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: You need not have taken this method, ſir, to let me ſee you were acquainted with my folly, whatever my inclinations are—.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, but Tom, ſuppoſe I give my conſent to your marrying this young woman?

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Your conſent, ſir!

sp.speaker: Roſſ.
sp.p: Come, ſir William, we have carried the jeſt far enough; I ſee your ſon is in a kind of embarraſſment, and I don't wonder at it; but this letter, which I received from him a few days before I left my father's houſe, will, I apprehend, expound the riddle.—He cannot be ſurprized that I ran away from a gentleman who expreſſed ſo much diſlike to me; and what has happened ſince chance brought us together in maſquerade, there is no occaſion for me to inform him of.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: What is all this? pray don't make a jeſt of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: May I never do an ill turn, Tom, if it is not truth; this is my friend's daughter.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Roſſ.
sp.p: Even ſo; 'tis very true indeed. In ſhort, you have not been a more whimſical gentleman, than I have a gentlewoman; but you ſee we were deſigned for one another, 'tis plain.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: I know not, madam, what I either hear or ſee, a thouſand things are crowding on my imagination; while, like one juſt wakened from a dream, I doubt which is reality, which deluſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well then, Tom, come into the air a bit, and recover yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Nay, dear ſir, have a little patience; do yon give her to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Give her to you! ay, that I do, and my bleſſing into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Then, ſir, I am the happieſt man in the world. I enquire no farther; here I fix the utmoſt limits of my hopes and happineſs.

lg.l: All I wiſh in her obtaining,
Fortune can no more impart;
Let my eyes, my thoughts explaining,
Speak the feelings of my heart.
Joy and pleaſure never ceaſing,
Love with length of years increaſing.
Thus my heart and hand ſurrender,
Here my faith and truth I plight;
Conſtant ſtill, and kind and tender,
May our flames burn ever bright.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Give you joy, ſir; and you fair lady.—And, under favour, I'll ſalute you, too, if there's no fear of jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: But may I believe this?—Pr'ythee tell me, dear Roſſetta.

sp.speaker: Roſſ.
sp.p: Step into the houſe and I'll tell you every thing.—I muſt intreat the good offices of Sir William, and Mr. Hawthorn, immediately; for I am in the utmoſt uneaſineſs about my poor friend Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Roſſ.
sp.p: I don't know, but I have reaſon to fear, I left her juſt now in very diſagreeable circumſtances, however, I hope, if there is any miſchief fallen out between her father and her lover—

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: The muſic maſter, I thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
What is there a lover in the caſe, may I never do an ill turn, but I am glad, ſo I am; for we'll make a double wedding; and, by way of celebrating it, take a trip to London, to ſhew the brides ſome of the
pleaſures of the town. And, maſter Hawthorn, you ſhall be of the party.—Come, children, go before us.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Thank you, ſir William, I'll go into the houſe with you, and to church, to ſee the young folks married; but, as to London, I beg to be excuſed.

lg.head: AIR XL.
lg.l: If ever I'm catch'd in thoſe regions of ſmoak,
That ſeat of confuſion and noiſe,
May I ne'er know the ſweets of a ſlumber unbroke,
Nor the pleaſures the country enjoys.
Nay, more, let them take me, to puniſh my ſin,
Where, gaping, the Cockneys they fleece,
Clap me up with their monſters, cry, maſters, walk in,
And ſhew me for two-pence a-piece.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Enter Juſtice WOODCOCK, Mrs. DEBORAH WOODCOCK, LUCINDA, EUSTACE, HODGE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Why, brother, do you think I can hear or ſee, or make uſe of my ſenſes? I tell you, I left that fellow locked up in her cloſet; and, while I have been with you, they have broke open the door, and got him out again.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Well, you hear what they ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: I care not what they ſay; it's you encourage them in their impudence.—Hark'e, huſſey, will you face me down that I did not lock the fellow up?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Really, aunt, I don't know what you mean; when you talk intelligibly, I'll anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Seriouſly madam, this is carrying the jeſt a little too far.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: What then, I did not catch you together in her chamber, nor over-hear your deſign of going off to night, nor find the bundles packt up—

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Why aunt you rave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Brother, as I am a chriſtian woman, ſhe confeſſed the whole affair to me from firſt to laſt: and in this very place was down upon her marrow-bones, for half an hour together, to beg I would conceal it from you.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: What ſirrah, would you brazen me too, take that (boxes him)

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: I wiſh you would keep your hands to yourſelf, you ſtrike me, becauſe you have been telling his worſhip ſtories.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Why ſiſter you are tipſey!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: I tipſey brother!—I—that never touch a drop of any thing ſtrong from year's end to year's end; but now and then a little Annyſeed water, when I have got the cholic.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Well, aunt, you have been complaining of the ſtomach-ach all day; and may have taken too powerful a doze of your cordial.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Come, come, I ſee well enough how it is, this is a lye of her own invention, to make herſelf appear wiſe: but you ſimpleton, did not you know I muſt find you out?

div.head: SCENE. X.
div.stage: Enter Sir WILLIAM MEADOWS, HAWTHORN, ROSSETTA Young, MEADOWS.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Bleſs me Sir! look who is yonder.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Cockſbones, Jack, honeſt Jack, are you there.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Plague on't, this rencounter is unlucky—Sir William your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Your ſervant again, and again, heartily your ſervant; may I never do an ill turn, but I am glad to meet you.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Pray Sir William, are you acquainted with this perſon?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, with Jack Euſtace? why he's my kinſman; his mother and I are couſin-germans once removed, and Jack's a very worthy young fellow; may I never do an ill turn if I tell you a word of a lye.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Well, but Sir William, let me tell you, you know nothing of the matter; this man is a muſic maſter; a thrummer of wire, and ſcraper of cat-gut, and teaches my daughter to ſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What Jack Euſtace a muſic maſter! no, no, I know him better.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p:
S'death, why ſhould I attempt to carry on this abſurd farce any longer?—What that gentleman tells you is very true, Sir; I am
•… muſic maſter indeed.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: You are not, you own it then?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p:
Nay, more Sir, I am as this lady has repreſented me, (pointing to Mrs. Deborah) your daughter's lover; whom with her own conſent, I did intend to have carried off this night; but now that Sir William Meadows is
here, to tell you who, and what I am; I throw myſelf upon your generoſity, from which I expect greater advantages, than I could reap from any impoſition on your unſuſpicious nature.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Well brother, what have you to ſay for yourſelf now? you have made a precious day's work of it! had my advice been taken: Oh I am aſhamed of you, but you are a weak man and it can't be helpt; however you ſhould let wiſer heads direct you.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Dear papa, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, do Sir forgive her; my couſin Jack, will make her a good huſband, I'll anſwer for it.

sp.speaker: Roſſ.
sp.p: Stand out of the way, and let me ſpeak two or three words to his worſhip;—Come my dear Sir, though you refuſe all the world, I am ſure you can deny me nothing: love is a venial fault—You know what I mean.—Be reconciled to your daughter, I conjure you, by the memory of our paſt affections—What not a word!

lg.head: AIR XLI.
lg.l: Go naughty man, I can't abide you;
Are then your vows ſo ſoon forgot?
Ah! now I ſee if I had tryed you;
What would have been my hopeful lot.
But hear I charge you—Make them happy;
Bleſs the fond pair, and crown their bliſs:
Come be a dear good-natured pappy;
And I'll reward you with a kiſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p:
Come turn out of the houſe; and be thankful my brother does not hang you, for he could
do it, he's a juſtice of peace;—turn out of the houſe I ſay:—

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Who gave you authority to turn him out of the houſe—he ſhall ſtay where he is,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: He ſhan't marry my niece.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Shan't he? but I'll ſhew you the difference now, I ſay he ſhall marry her, and what will you do about it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: And you will give him your eſtate too, will you?

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes I will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Why I am ſure he's a vagabond.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: I like him the better, I would have him a vagabond.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Brother brother!

sp.speaker: Hawthorn.
sp.p: Come, come, madam all's very well, and I ſee my neighbour is what I always thought him, a man of ſenſe and prudence.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: May I never do an ill turn, but I ſay ſo too.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Here young fellow, take my daughter; and bleſs you both together; but hark you, no money till I dye; obſerve that.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Sir in giving me your daughter, you beſtow upon me more than the whole world would be without her.

lg.l: The merchant whoſe veſſel, the winds made their ſport
At laſt thus arrives with his treaſure in port;
His labour requited, his duty he pays;
His dangers are paſt, and his heart is at eaſe.
Were monarchs contending to make me a bride,
Undazzled I'd look on their ſplendour and pride;
Refuſed ſhould their crowns, and their palaces be,
Contented to live in a cottage with thee.
On Earth, if there's ought of ſubſtantial delight,
'Tis ſure when like us a fond couple unite;
When bleſſed in each other their ſtruggles are o'er,
And pleaſures are heighten'd by pains gone before.

sp.speaker: Roſſ.
sp.p: Dear Lucinda, if words could convey the tranſports of my heart upon this occaſion—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Words are the tools of hypocrites, the pretenders to friendſhip; only let us reſolve to preſerve our eſteem for each other.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Dear Jack, I little thought we ſhould ever meet in ſuch odd circumſtances—but here has been the ſtrangeſt buſineſs between this lady and me—

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: What then Mrs. Roſsetta, are you turned falſe-hearted after all; will you marry Thomas the gardener, and did I forſake Madge for this?

sp.speaker: Roſſ.
Hodge.
sp.p: N—ah.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p:
Adds me Sir, here are ſome of your neighbours
come to viſit you, and I ſuppoſe, to make up the company of your ſtatute ball; yonder's muſic too I ſee, ſhall we enjoy ourſelves; if ſo give me your hand—

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Why here's my hand, and we will enjoy ourſelves, heaven bleſs you both children I ſay,—ſiſter Deborah, you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: You are a fool brother, and mark my words—But I'll give myſelf no more trouble about you.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Fidlers ſtrike up.

lg.head: AIR. XLIII.
lg.l: Hence with cares complaints and frowning,
Welcome jollity and joy;
Ev'ry grief in pleaſure drowning,
Mirth this happy night employ:
Let's to friendſhip do our duty;
Laugh and ſing ſome good old ſtrain,
Drink a health to love and beauty,
May they long in triumph reign.

div.head: A Table of the Songs, with the names of the ſeveral compoſers.
div.p: N B. Thoſe marked thus * were compoſed on purpoſe for this Opera.

list.item: A New Overture by Mr. Abel.

list.head: ACT I.
list.label: 1 Hope thou nurſe of young deſire
2 Whence can you inherit
3 My heart's my own my will is free
4 When once love's ſubtle poiſon gains
5* Oh had I been by fate decreed
6 Gentle youth ah tell me why
7* Still in hopes to get the better
8 There was a jolly miller once
9 Let gay ones and great
10 The honeſt heart whoſe thoughts are free
11 Well well ſay no more
12 Cupid God of ſoft perſuaſion
13 How happy were my days till now
14 The court and the city fine folks may extol
15 A Medley

list.head: ACT II.
list.label: 16 We women like weak Indians trade
17 Think my faireſt how delay
18* Believe me dear aunt
19 When I followed a laſs that was froward and ſhy
20 Let rakes and libertines reſign'd
21 How bleſt the maid whoſe boſom
22 In vain I every art aſſay
23 Begone I agree
24 Oh how ſhall I in language weak
25 Young I am and ſore afraid
26 Zooks neighbour ne'er bluſh for a trifle like this
27 My Dolly was the faireſt thing
28 Oh Hymen propitious receive in thy train
29 Was ever poor fellow ſo plagued with a vixen
30 Ceaſe ſeducers pride to take
31 Since Hodge proves ungrateful, no farther I'll ſeek
32* Well come let us hear what the ſwain muſt poſſeſs.

list.head: ACT III.
list.label: 33 The world is a well furniſhed table
34 It is not wealth, it is not birth
35* The traveller benighted
36 If ever a fond inclination
37 Plague o'theſe wenches they make ſuch a pother
38* How much ſuperior beauty aws
39 When we ſee a lover languiſh
40 All I wiſh in her obtaining
41 If ever I am catched in thoſe regions of ſmoke
42*Go naughty man I can't abide you
43 The merchant whoſe veſſel the winds make their ſport
44 Hence with cares complaints and frowing
